conversation.content: [frozen] I got the work order for upgrading the executive floor security system, but I didn't realize—God, I didn't know you worked here, or that you'd changed your name.
[carefully neutral] It's been twenty years, Jamie. I wasn't sure you'd recognize me. The receptionist said our installer was running late, but she didn't mention who was coming. [exhales slowly]
Mom kept your picture on the mantle even after you left, so yeah, I recognize you despite the gray hair and the expensive suit.
[softly] How is she? Your mother, I mean. The last I heard through mutual friends was that she remarried, someone from her book club.
[bitter laugh] She died three years ago. Cancer. The man from the book club turned out to be decent though—he stayed through the chemo, the hospice, everything you missed.
[voice cracking] I didn't know. Jamie, I swear I didn't know she was sick. I would have—[pause]—I should have been checking in somehow.
Would you have come back? Because she asked for you near the end, kept saying she forgave you for leaving, for choosing your career over us. [quieter] I never told her I'd found you.
[urgently] You knew where I was? How long have you known I was here practicing law, building this life without you both in it?
Five years. I install security systems for half the firms in the city, and your name came up in a background check. [sighs] Patricia Chen, formerly Patrick Chen, senior partner since 2018.
[gently] The transition was the hardest thing I ever did, but staying would have been harder. Your mother deserved someone who could be fully present, not someone dying inside every single day.
[struggling] I get that now, I really do, but understanding it as an adult doesn't erase what it felt like as a thirteen-year-old watching my dad disappear.

I wrote you letters every week for two years, explaining everything, apologizing, trying to maintain some connection, but your mother sent them all back unopened. [voice breaking] Eventually I stopped trying.
[shocked] She never told me about any letters. We moved three times that first year, and she said you didn't care enough to find us.

[firmly] I hired a private investigator. I knew every address, every school you attended. I sent birthday cards, graduation money, [exhales shakily], everything returned with 'refused' written across it.
Jesus. She constructed this whole narrative about you abandoning us, and I built my entire identity around being the kid whose father didn't want them. [voice cracking] What else was a lie?
[tenderly] You weren't unwanted.
[wavering] I should probably start the installation. The work order says you need upgraded sensors on all entry points and a new panic room protocol for the senior partners' offices.
[hopefully] The installation will take what, three or four hours? Maybe we could talk while you work, or grab dinner after if you're willing to try.
[quietly decisive] I've got nothing scheduled after this. And Mom's gone, so there's no one left to protect from the truth anymore. [pause] We could try dinner.
There's a quiet place two blocks over where we can actually hear each other talk, and Jamie—thank you for not just walking out when you saw me.

scenario: An alarm system installer arrives to upgrade security at a prestigious law firm, only to discover the senior partner demanding the work is their estranged parent who transitioned and disappeared twenty years ago.
